00028 const int NumCodeBytes = 16;  // Number of code bytes to record.
00029 const int MaxStackDump = 2048;      // Maximum number of DWORDS in stack dumps.
00030 const int StackColumns = 8;         // Number of columns in stack dump.
00031 
00032 #define     ONEK              1024
00033 #define     SIXTYFOURK        (64*ONEK)
00034 #define     ONEM              (ONEK*ONEK)
00035 #define     ONEG              (ONEK*ONEK*ONEK)

00056 INT32 RecordExceptionInfo( EXCEPTION_POINTERS *pExceptInfo )
00057 {
00058       EXCEPTION_RECORD Record;
00059       CONTEXT     Context;
00060       CHAR8       zFileName[512];
00061       CHAR8       zDate[512];
00062       CHAR8       zTime[512];
00063       HWFILE      hFile;
00064       CHAR8       zString[2048];
00065       SYSTEMTIME SysTime;
00066       CHAR8       zNewLine[] = "\r\n";
00067 
00068 
00069       //create local copies of the exception info
00070       memcpy( &Record, pExceptInfo->ExceptionRecord , sizeof( EXCEPTION_RECORD ) );
00071       memcpy( &Context, pExceptInfo->ContextRecord, sizeof( CONTEXT ) );
00072 
00073 
00074       //
00075       //     Open a file to output the current state of the game
00076       //
00077 
00078 
00079       // Get the current time
00080       GetLocalTime( &SysTime );
00081 
00082       //create a date string
00083       sprintf( zDate, "%02d_%02d_%d", SysTime.wDay, SysTime.wMonth, SysTime.wYear );
00084 
00085       //create a time string
00086       sprintf( zTime, "%02d_%02d", SysTime.wHour, SysTime.wMinute );
00087 
00088       //create the crash file
00089       sprintf( zFileName, "Crash Report_%s___%s.txt", zDate, zTime );
00090 
00091       // create the save game file
00092       hFile = FileOpen( zFileName, FILE_ACCESS_WRITE | FILE_OPEN_ALWAYS, FALSE );
00093       if( !hFile )
00094       {
00095             FileClose( hFile );
00096             return( 0 );
00097       }
00098 
00099       //
00100       // Display the version number
00101       //
00102 #ifdef JA2
00103 
00104       //Dispay Ja's version number
00105       ErrorLog( hFile, "%S: %s.  %S",zVersionLabel, czVersionNumber, zTrackingNumber );
00106 
00107       //Insert a new line
00108       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00109 
00110       //Insert a new line
00111       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00112 #endif
00113 
00114 
00115 
00116       //
00117       // Write out the current state of the system
00118       //
00119 
00120       GetAndDisplayModuleAndSystemInfo( hFile, &Context );
00121 
00122 
00123       //Insert a new line
00124       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00125 
00126       //Display the address of where the exception occured
00127       sprintf( zString, "Exception occured at address: 0x%08x\r\n", Record.ExceptionAddress );
00128       ErrorLog( hFile, zString );
00129 
00130 
00131       //if the exception was an access violation, display the offending address
00132       if( Record.ExceptionCode == EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION && Record.NumberParameters != 0 )
00133       {
00134             if( Record.ExceptionInformation[0] != 0 )
00135             {
00136                   //Display the address of where the access violation occured
00137                   sprintf( zString, "\tWrite Access Violation at: 0x%08x\r\n", Record.ExceptionInformation[1] );
00138             }
00139             else
00140             {
00141                   //Display the address of where the access violation occured
00142                   sprintf( zString, "\tWrite Access Violation at: 0x%08x\r\n", Record.ExceptionInformation[1] );
00143             }
00144 
00145             ErrorLog( hFile, zString );
00146       }
00147 
00148 
00149       //Insert a new line
00150       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00151 
00152       //Display the exception that caused this
00153       sprintf( zString, "Exact Error Message \r\n \"%s\"\r\n", GetExceptionString( Record.ExceptionCode ) );
00154       ErrorLog( hFile, zString );
00155 
00156       //Insert a new line
00157       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00158 
00159       //Dispay if the code 'could' continue
00160       if( Record.ExceptionFlags != 0 )
00161             sprintf( zString, "%s\r\n", "The game 'can NOT' continue" );
00162       else
00163             sprintf( zString, "%s\r\n", "The game 'CAN' continue" );
00164       ErrorLog( hFile, zString );
00165 
00166 
00167       //Insert a new line
00168       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00169       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00170 
00171 
00172       //
00173       // Display the current context information
00174       //
00175       DisplayRegisters( hFile, &Context );
00176 
00177       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00178       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00179 
00180       //display the stack ( call stack + local variables )
00181       DisplayStack( hFile, &Context);
00182 
00183       //Display some spaces
00184       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00185       ErrorLog( hFile, zNewLine );
00186 
00187       //Display all modules currently loaded
00188       RecordModuleList(hFile );
00189 
00190 
00191       //eee
00192 
00193       FileClose( hFile );
00194 
00195       return( EXCEPTION_EXECUTE_HANDLER );
00196 }

00200 void ErrorLog( HWFILE hFile, char* Format, ...)
00201 {
00202       char buffer[2000];      // wvsprintf never prints more than one K.
00203       UINT32      uiNumBytesWritten=0;
00204       UINT32      uiStringWidth;
00205       va_list arglist;
00206       va_start( arglist, Format);
00207       wvsprintf(buffer, Format, arglist);
00208       va_end( arglist);
00209 
00210       //WriteFile(LogFile, buffer, lstrlen(buffer), &NumBytes, 0);
00211 
00212 
00213       uiStringWidth = lstrlen(buffer);
00214 
00215       //write out the string
00216       FileWrite( hFile, buffer, uiStringWidth, &uiNumBytesWritten );
00217       if( uiNumBytesWritten != uiStringWidth )
00218       {
00219             FileClose( hFile );
00220             return;
00221       }
00222 
00223 }
00224 
00225 STR   GetExceptionString( DWORD uiExceptionCode )
00226 {
00227       switch( uiExceptionCode )
00228       {
00229             case EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION:
00230                   return( "The thread tried to read from or write to a virtual address for which it does not have the appropriate access.");
00231                   break;
00232             case EXCEPTION_ARRAY_BOUNDS_EXCEEDED:
00233                   return( "The thread tried to access an array element that is out of bounds and the underlying hardware supports bounds checking.");
00234             case EXCEPTION_BREAKPOINT:
00235                   return( "A breakpoint was encountered.");
00236             case EXCEPTION_DATATYPE_MISALIGNMENT:
00237                   return( "The thread tried to read or write data that is misaligned on hardware that does not provide alignment. For example, 16-bit values must be aligned on 2-byte boundaries; 32-bit values on 4-byte boundaries, and so on.");
00238             case EXCEPTION_FLT_DENORMAL_OPERAND:
00239                   return( "One of the operands in a floating-point operation is denormal. A denormal value is one that is too small to represent as a standard floating-point value.");
00240             case EXCEPTION_FLT_DIVIDE_BY_ZERO:
00241                   return( "The thread tried to divide a floating-point value by a floating-point divisor of zero.");
00242             case EXCEPTION_FLT_INEXACT_RESULT:
00243                   return( "The result of a floating-point operation cannot be represented exactly as a decimal fraction.");
00244             case EXCEPTION_FLT_INVALID_OPERATION:
00245                   return( "This exception represents any floating-point exception not included in this list.");
00246             case EXCEPTION_FLT_OVERFLOW:
00247                   return( "The exponent of a floating-point operation is greater than the magnitude allowed by the corresponding type.");
00248             case EXCEPTION_FLT_STACK_CHECK:
00249                   return( "The stack overflowed or underflowed as the result of a floating-point operation.");
00250             case EXCEPTION_FLT_UNDERFLOW:
00251                   return( "The exponent of a floating-point operation is less than the magnitude allowed by the corresponding type.");
00252             case EXCEPTION_ILLEGAL_INSTRUCTION:
00253                   return( "The thread tried to execute an invalid instruction.");
00254             case EXCEPTION_IN_PAGE_ERROR:
00255                   return( "The thread tried to access a page that was not present, and the system was unable to load the page. For example, this exception might occur if a network connection is lost while running a program over the network.");
00256             case EXCEPTION_INT_DIVIDE_BY_ZERO:
00257                   return( "The thread tried to divide an integer value by an integer divisor of zero.");
00258             case EXCEPTION_INT_OVERFLOW:
00259                   return( "The result of an integer operation caused a carry out of the most significant bit of the result.");
00260             case EXCEPTION_INVALID_DISPOSITION:
00261                   return( "An exception handler returned an invalid disposition to the exception dispatcher. Programmers using a high-level language such as C should never encounter this exception.");
00262             case EXCEPTION_NONCONTINUABLE_EXCEPTION:
00263                   return( "The thread tried to continue execution after a noncontinuable exception occurred.");
00264             case EXCEPTION_PRIV_INSTRUCTION:
00265                   return( "The thread tried to execute an instruction whose operation is not allowed in the current machine mode."); 
00266             case EXCEPTION_SINGLE_STEP:
00267                   return( "A trace trap or other single-instruction mechanism signaled that one instruction has been executed.");
00268             case EXCEPTION_STACK_OVERFLOW:
00269                   return( "The thread used up its stack.");
00270 
00271             default:
00272                   return("Exception not in case ");
00273                   break;
00274       }
00275 }

00278 void DisplayRegisters( HWFILE hFile, CONTEXT    *pContext )
00279 {
00280       ErrorLog( hFile, "Registers:\r\n");
00281       ErrorLog( hFile, "\tEAX=%08x CS=%04x EIP=%08x EFLGS=%08x\r\n",
00282                         pContext->Eax, pContext->SegCs, pContext->Eip, pContext->EFlags);
00283       ErrorLog( hFile, "\tEBX=%08x SS=%04x ESP=%08x EBP=%08x\r\n",
00284                         pContext->Ebx, pContext->SegSs, pContext->Esp, pContext->Ebp);
00285       ErrorLog( hFile, "\tECX=%08x DS=%04x ESI=%08x FS=%04x\r\n",
00286                         pContext->Ecx, pContext->SegDs, pContext->Esi, pContext->SegFs);
00287       ErrorLog( hFile, "\tEDX=%08x ES=%04x EDI=%08x GS=%04x\r\n",
00288                         pContext->Edx, pContext->SegEs, pContext->Edi, pContext->SegGs);
00289 //    ErrorLog( hFile, "Bytes at CS:EIP:\r\n");
00290 }

00292 BOOLEAN GetAndDisplayModuleAndSystemInfo( HWFILE hFile, CONTEXT *pContext )
00293 {
00294       char zFileName[2048];
00295       char zString[2048];
00296       SYSTEM_INFO SystemInfo;
00297       MEMORYSTATUS      MemInfo;
00298 //    MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION      MemBasicInfo;
00299       size_t PageSize;
00300       size_t pageNum = 0;
00301       FILETIME    LastWriteTime;
00302 
00303       if( GetModuleFileName(0, zFileName, sizeof(zFileName) ) == 0)
00304       {
00305             return( FALSE );
00306       }
00307 
00308       MemInfo.dwLength = sizeof(MemInfo);
00309       GlobalMemoryStatus(&MemInfo);
00310 
00311       //Display the filename
00312       ErrorLog( hFile, "File:\r\n\t%s\r\n", zFileName);
00313 
00314 
00315       //Get the time the file was created
00316       if (GetFileTime(GetRealFileHandleFromFileManFileHandle( hFile ), 0, 0, &LastWriteTime))
00317       {
00318             PrintTime( zString, LastWriteTime);
00319       
00320             ErrorLog( hFile, "\tFile created on: %s\r\n", zString );
00321       }
00322 
00323 
00324       //Get cpu type and number
00325       GetSystemInfo(&SystemInfo);
00326       ErrorLog( hFile, "\t%d type %d processor.\r\n", SystemInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors, SystemInfo.dwProcessorType );
00327 
00328       //Get free ram
00329       ErrorLog( hFile, "\tTotal Physical Memory: %d Megs.\r\n", MemInfo.dwTotalPhys/(1024*1024) );
00330 
00331 
00332       PageSize = SystemInfo.dwPageSize;
00333 
00334       pageNum = 0;
00335 
00336 /*
00337       //Get current instruction pointer
00338       if( VirtualQuery((void *)(pageNum * PageSize), &MemBasicInfo, sizeof(MemBasicInfo) ) )
00339       {
00340             if (MemBasicInfo.RegionSize > 0)
00341             {
00342                   ErrorLog( hFile, "\r\n\r\nJagged is loaded into memory at: 0x%08d.\r\n", MemBasicInfo.AllocationBase );
00343             }
00344       }
00345 */
00346 
00347       ErrorLog( hFile, "Segment( CS:EIP ):\t%04x:%08x.\r\n", pContext->SegCs, pContext->Eip );
00348 
00349       return( TRUE );
00350 }

00354 //
00355 // This code for this function is based ( stolen ) from Bruce Dawson's article in Game Developer Magazine Jan 99
00356 //
00357 BOOLEAN DisplayStack( HWFILE hFile, CONTEXT     *pContext  )
00358 {
00359       int Count = 0;
00360       char  buffer[1000] = "";
00361       const int safetyzone = 50;
00362       char* nearend = buffer + sizeof(buffer) - safetyzone;
00363       char* output = buffer;
00364 
00365       // Time to print part or all of the stack to the error log. This allows
00366       // us to figure out the call stack, parameters, local variables, etc.
00367             ErrorLog( hFile, "Stack dump:\r\n" );
00368 
00369       __try
00370       {
00371             // Esp contains the bottom of the stack, or at least the bottom of
00372             // the currently used area.
00373             DWORD* pStack = (DWORD *)pContext->Esp;
00374             DWORD* pStackTop;
00375             __asm
00376             {
00377                   // Load the top (highest address) of the stack from the
00378                   // thread information block. It will be found there in
00379                   // Win9x and Windows NT.
00380                   mov   eax, fs:[4]
00381                   mov pStackTop, eax
00382             }
00383             if (pStackTop > pStack + MaxStackDump)
00384                   pStackTop = pStack + MaxStackDump;
00385 
00386 
00387             // Too many calls to WriteFile can take a long time, causing
00388             // confusing delays when programs crash. Therefore I implemented
00389             // simple buffering for the stack dumping code instead of calling
00390             // hprintf directly.
00391 
00392             while (pStack + 1 <= pStackTop)
00393             {
00394                   char *Suffix = " ";
00395 
00396                   if ((Count % StackColumns) == 0)
00397                         output += wsprintf(output, "%08x: ", pStack);
00398 
00399                   if ((++Count % StackColumns) == 0 || pStack + 2 > pStackTop)
00400                         Suffix = "\r\n";
00401                   output += wsprintf(output, "%08x%s", *pStack, Suffix);
00402                   pStack++;
00403       
00404                   // Check for when the buffer is almost full, and flush it to disk.
00405                   if (output > nearend)
00406                   {
00407                         ErrorLog( hFile, "%s", buffer);
00408                         buffer[0] = 0;
00409                         output = buffer;
00410                   }
00411             }
00412             // Print out any final characters from the cache.
00413             ErrorLog( hFile, "%s", buffer);
00414       }
00415       __except(EXCEPTION_EXECUTE_HANDLER)
00416       {
00417             ErrorLog( hFile, "Exception encountered during stack dump.\r\n");
00418       }
00419 
00420       return( TRUE );
00421 }

00424 //
00425 // This code for this function is ( stolen :) from Bruce Dawson's article in Game Developer Magazine Jan 99
00426 //
00427 
00428 // Print the specified FILETIME to output in a human readable format,
00429 // without using the C run time.
00430 
00431 void PrintTime(char *output, FILETIME TimeToPrint)
00432 {
00433       WORD Date, Time;
00434       if (FileTimeToLocalFileTime(&TimeToPrint, &TimeToPrint) &&
00435                         FileTimeToDosDateTime(&TimeToPrint, &Date, &Time))
00436       {
00437             // What a silly way to print out the file date/time. Oh well,
00438             // it works, and I'm not aware of a cleaner way to do it.
00439             wsprintf(output, "%02d/%02d/%d %02d:%02d:%02d",
00440                               (Date / 32) & 15, Date & 31, (Date / 512) + 1980,
00441                               (Time / 2048), (Time / 32) & 63, (Time & 31) * 2);
00442       }
00443       else
00444             output[0] = 0;
00445 }

00453 //
00454 // This code for this function is ( stolen :) from Bruce Dawson's article in Game Developer Magazine Jan 99
00455 //
00456 
00457 // Scan memory looking for code modules (DLLs or EXEs). VirtualQuery is used
00458 // to find all the blocks of address space that were reserved or committed,
00459 // and ShowModuleInfo will display module information if they are code
00460 // modules.
00461 
00462 
00463 void RecordModuleList(HWFILE hFile )
00464 {
00465       ErrorLog( hFile, "\r\n"
00466                                "Module list: names, addresses, sizes, time stamps "
00467                   "and file times:\r\n");
00468       SYSTEM_INFO SystemInfo;
00469       GetSystemInfo(&SystemInfo);
00470       const size_t PageSize = SystemInfo.dwPageSize;
00471       // Set NumPages to the number of pages in the 4GByte address space,
00472       // while being careful to avoid overflowing ints.
00473       const size_t NumPages = 4 * size_t(ONEG / PageSize);
00474       size_t pageNum = 0;
00475       void *LastAllocationBase = 0;
00476       while (pageNum < NumPages)
00477       {
00478             MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION      MemInfo;
00479             if (VirtualQuery((void *)(pageNum * PageSize), &MemInfo,
00480                               sizeof(MemInfo)))
00481             {
00482                   if (MemInfo.RegionSize > 0)
00483                   {
00484                         // Adjust the page number to skip over this block of memory.
00485                         pageNum += MemInfo.RegionSize / PageSize;
00486                         if (MemInfo.State == MEM_COMMIT && MemInfo.AllocationBase >
00487                                           LastAllocationBase)
00488                         {
00489                               // Look for new blocks of committed memory, and try
00490                               // recording their module names - this will fail
00491                               // gracefully if they aren't code modules.
00492                               LastAllocationBase = MemInfo.AllocationBase;
00493                               ShowModuleInfo(hFile, (HINSTANCE)LastAllocationBase);
00494                         }
00495                   }
00496                   else
00497                         pageNum += SIXTYFOURK / PageSize;
00498             }
00499             else
00500                   pageNum += SIXTYFOURK / PageSize;
00501             // If VirtualQuery fails we advance by 64K because that is the
00502             // granularity of address space doled out by VirtualAlloc().
00503       }
00504 }
00505 
00506 
00507 
00508 //
00509 // This code for this function is ( stolen :) from Bruce Dawson's article in Game Developer Magazine Jan 99
00510 //
00511 static void ShowModuleInfo(HWFILE hFile, HINSTANCE ModuleHandle)
00512 {
00513       char ModName[MAX_PATH];
00514       __try
00515       {
00516             if (GetModuleFileName(ModuleHandle, ModName, sizeof(ModName)) > 0)
00517             {
00518                   // If GetModuleFileName returns greater than zero then this must
00519                   // be a valid code module address. Therefore we can try to walk
00520                   // our way through its structures to find the link time stamp.
00521                   IMAGE_DOS_HEADER *DosHeader = (IMAGE_DOS_HEADER*)ModuleHandle;
00522                 if (IMAGE_DOS_SIGNATURE != DosHeader->e_magic)
00523                 return;
00524                   IMAGE_NT_HEADERS *NTHeader = (IMAGE_NT_HEADERS*)((char *)DosHeader
00525                                     + DosHeader->e_lfanew);
00526                 if (IMAGE_NT_SIGNATURE != NTHeader->Signature)
00527                 return;
00528                   // Open the code module file so that we can get its file date
00529                   // and size.
00530                   HANDLE ModuleFile = CreateFile(ModName, GENERIC_READ,
00531                                     FILE_SHARE_READ, 0, OPEN_EXISTING,
00532                                     FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NORMAL, 0);
00533                   char TimeBuffer[100] = "";
00534                   DWORD FileSize = 0;
00535                   if (ModuleFile != INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE)
00536                   {
00537                         FileSize = GetFileSize(ModuleFile, 0);
00538                         FILETIME    LastWriteTime;
00539                         if (GetFileTime(ModuleFile, 0, 0, &LastWriteTime))
00540                         {
00541                               wsprintf(TimeBuffer, " - file date is ");
00542                               PrintTime(TimeBuffer + lstrlen(TimeBuffer), LastWriteTime);
00543                         }
00544                         CloseHandle(ModuleFile);
00545                   }
00546                   ErrorLog( hFile, "%-35s, loaded at 0x%08x - %7d bytes - %08x%s\r\n",
00547                                     ModName, ModuleHandle, FileSize,
00548                                     NTHeader->FileHeader.TimeDateStamp, TimeBuffer);
00549             }
00550       }
00551       // Handle any exceptions by continuing from this point.
00552       __except(EXCEPTION_EXECUTE_HANDLER)
00553       {
00554       }
00555 }
